thread.title: Watson part of memorable U.S. win in Presidents Cup
thread.title_full: Watson part of memorable U.S. win in Presidents Cup

title: Watson part of memorable U.S. win in Presidents Cup
text:
Watson part of memorable U.S. win in Presidents Cup Bill Vilona, pnj.com 2:30 a.m. CDT October 11, 2015 United States' J.B. Holmes, left, and teammate Bubba Watson celebrate on the ninth hole during their four ball match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) (Photo: AP) 
Bubba Watson experienced one of the lowest moments a year ago with a U.S. team in international golf competition. 
He was part of one of the most memorable early Sunday morning at the Presidents Cup. 
After initially being glum about missing a short putt that would have won his match outright, Watson then cheered on Bill Haas, son of US captain Jay Haas, as he clinched a U.S victory against the International Team on the final hole and final match. It became a dramatic finish in one of the best match play events in pro golf. 
For the U.S, which sustained a lopsided loss a year ago in the Ryder Cup, the win helped erase that memory for several of the players like Watson who were on that team. 
The U.S. has dominated the Presidents Cup, winning nine of 11 times these matches were staged, but none closer than this one at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club in South Korea. The U.S prevailed 15.5 to 14.5. 
Playing as a captain's pick for his father, Haas was in the last of 12 matches. It became the deciding one. Carrying a 1-up lead against South Korea's Bae Sang-moon, Haas was in good shape in a green side bunker in 2 on the par-5 18th. Bae Sang-moon then flubbed his third shot chip, then put the next one well past the hole. After Haas blasted to about 4 feet, the match was conceded and the U.S. won. 
Watson, the Milton High grad, who is building a home in Pensacola, finished 2-1-2 in all matches. He had a three hole lead heading into the final 8 holes, in his match against Thailand's Thongchai Jaidee, but Watson bogeyed holes No. 16 and No. 17 and both players made par on 18 to end all square. 
But it was a big for Watson, who played well during most of the four day competition. 
He teammed with friend J.B. Holmes to form a standout duo in the foursomes and four-ball matches. 
After an eventful weekend, which included Watson having his pink-shaft driver snap on the practice range moments before starting Friday’s matches, the Presidents Cup cam down to the 12 singles matches. 
Watson is the fifth match which started at 8:07 p.m. Saturday (Pensacola time); Holmes preceded him in the fourth match. Their only loss was 1-up earlier Saturday against Louis Oosthuizen and Branden Grace. Jordan Spieth having fun as USA holds narrow lead in Presidents Cup 
On Friday, Watson played the first hole with a 3-wood in his alternate-shot match, while team officials raced back to the hotel to get Watson’s second driver. Assistant U.S. captain Fred Couples delivered it while waving it in the air like a sword as he was transported on the course in a cart. 
Earlier this week, Watson said the greens are deceptive enough that it presents the hardest element to solve. 
“So for this competition, and especially (Thursday), these tricky greens, it's who makes putts,” Watson said. “If you look, we started off hot, we started off making the putts and then we ended up making the putts. Pairings set for final day as U.S. holds narrow lead at Presidents Cup 
“Right in the middle both teams were not making putts. They looked good, but they didn't go in, so it was all about putting, and this golf course is going to be about putting and controlling the speed and making the ten footers.” 
Following this event, Watson is expected to return to Pensacola where he is hosting his annual Bubba Bash for the first time in this community. The event features headline band Rascal Flatts performing Oct. 24 at the Bay Center. 12 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.pnj.com/1LoEQnV TOP VIDEOS
